Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: New Technologies for Genome-Scale Comparative NcRNA Identification
Award.AbstractNarration:
CAREER: New Technologies for Genome-Scale Comparative NcRNA Identification

Michigan State University is awarded a grant from the Faculty Early Career Development program (CAREER) to develop new technologies for genome-scale comparative noncoding RNA (ncRNA) identification. ncRNAs, which are not translated into protein but function directly as RNA, play diverse and important roles in many biochemical processes. Annotating ncRNAs in different organisms is thus highly important to modern biology. Among numerous efforts made for ncRNA detection, a few programs can be practically applied to whole genomes or large-scale databases. However, these genome-scale tools rely on conventional comparative sequence analysis, which cannot not effectively account for structural conservation in homologous ncRNAs and thus jeopardizes the sensitivity and accuracy of structured ncRNA search. In order to address the need of sensitive and fast large-scale ncRNA search, this project focuses on the development of novel and improved ncRNA detection algorithms that combine the efficiency of conventional sequence comparison tools and the structural features of ncRNAs. The specific objectives are: (1) fast known ncRNA identification algorithms and tools that can efficiently classify a large number of putative ncRNAs into corresponding ncRNA families, (2) highly efficient genome-scale sequence comparison algorithms for ncRNA homology search, and (3) a novel ncRNA structure modeling and comparison method.

The research goals of this project and the training needs of computational biology are integrated with the following educational objectives and plans. 1) Improve the awareness of computational biology as an important research area among students in biology and engineering. A new computational biology course for both senior undergraduates and graduates has been designed and is offered every fall. 2) Improve cross-disciplinary research training experiences for graduate and undergraduate students through MSU's Quantitative Biology Initiative (QBI) dual-major degree program. 3) Encourage retention and recruitment of underrepresented groups in computational biology related majors. The PI will continue to attend the K-12 women students outreach through Women in Engineering Summer Program every year, and help undergraduate women students through Women In Computing organization at MSU.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project produced an efficient and reliable annotation of noncoding RNA (ncRNA) genes in large-scale sequence database, including complete mammalian genomes, transcriptomes, or metagenomic data sets. And its success relies on the innovative representation of both sequence and structural features of ncRNAs. These novel representations allowed application of core technologies for fast sequence comparison and search to ncRNA identification. Advances of these much-needed ncRNA identification technologies implemented in this project can contribute to the completion of a complete ncRNA annotation map in different organisms.

The final outputs of this proposed project included both well-documented bioinformatics tools and our ncRNA annotation results on different input datasets. These tools and datasets can be widely used by biologists to study working mechanisms of different types of ncRNAs. All tools developed in this project are freely available as open source software.

This project provided excellent teaching materials for both undergraduate and graduate level courses. Many algorithms used in our research are aligned well with several important topics in the undergraduate algorithm
course, including hashing based indexing, sorting, and dynamic programming. Therefore, we have introduced a computational biology component to our undergraduate-level algorithm and data structure course using canonical
bioinformatics problems as examples and exercises. In addition, the PI has developed a new course on probabilistic models and algorithms in bioinformatics. Both canonical bioinformatics problems and new developments of next-generation sequencing analysis were incorporated in this new course.

This project provided extensive research ability training for both graduate students and undergraduate students. Through working on this project, the graduate students have achieved significantly better understanding of noncoding RNA search in large-scale genomic data set. Along this, their overall knowledge about computational biology/bioinformatics is expanded. Their programming skills and analyzing abilities are improved while implementing different parts of the proposed activities. All these training prepare them well for their future careers, which have been proven by their job hunting experiences.

This project provides training students for minority students. Of the supported Ph.D. students, two are female students. Both of them got their Ph.D. through working on this project and found industrial and academic jobs, respectively after graduation. 

We have broadly disseminated the results to communities of interest. All the major research activities were reported in Bioinforamtics conferences and on-campus poster competitions. In particular, we presented our work in the annual poster competition in Engineering School. Both graduate and undergraduate students from Engineering School attended this event and our work can raise their awareness of Bioinformatics as an important branch of interdisciplinary research.


Last Modified: 09/22/2017
Modified by: Yanni Sun
